title: Children memory EMT
text:
This is a basic report site for the Memory tests with the children subjects.
Planning to submit it to the International Journal of Behavioral Development: Sage Journals

title: VR Children EMT test Reports
text:
A total of 47 children participated in the study. The average age was 69.89 months (SD = 5.4, Min = 60, Max = 83). Children were recruited from 5 schools.


To simplify theoutput, we decided to keep only the object location error, as the object location and objec torder are heavilly correlated anyways





Effect sizes were labelled following Funder's (2019) recommendations.

The Kendall's rank correlation tau between
df_location_object_error$incorrect_location_order and
df_location_object_error$incorrect_object_order is positive, statistically
significant, and very large (tau = 1.00, z = 12.55, p < .001)

text:
A total of 47 children participated in the study. The average age was 69.89 months (SD = 5.4, Min = 60, Max = 83). Children were recruited from 5 schools.

The Kendall's rank correlation tau between
df_location_object_error$incorrect_location_order and
df_location_object_error$incorrect_object_order is positive, statistically
significant, and very large (tau = 1.00, z = 12.55, p < .001)

title: VR Children EMT test Reports
text:
Descriptives






Errors






Tip



CO = correct objects/správné předměty resp. Jejich Chyby (už přepočítáno)
OPE = object position errors/chyby v pozici
OOE = object order errors/chyby v pořadí předmětu
LOE = location order errors/chyby v pořadí pozice


These errors were renamed to a bit clearer naming schemes to prevent OOE, OPE etc.






Tip



The errors come in four different types:

selection error: the participant selected the wrong item
incorrect_placement: the participant placed the item at a wrong position
incorrect_object_order: the participant placed the item at a wrong order
incorrect_location_order: the participant placed the item at a location in a wrong order?

title: VR Children EMT test Reports
text:
Difficulty and accuracy






Relative accuracy/error
As there is a difference in the potential number of errors possible at different difficulties, we also calculated the relative error (errors/max possible errors) relative accuracy (1 - errors/max posibble errors). So the number 1 in relative accuracy means the best possible performance.





So it looks like increasing number of items decreases performance. The selection seems to be relatively stable, but the object order had more thn half the errors in the 5 items difficulty.






Warning



Just to remind, if one location is incorrect, then more locations will be incorrect after that, as the participant will not be able to place the objects correctly. This will overestimate the number of errors in later trials, as the errors are not independent and it is almost impossible to do “just one error” in the order of objects. Selection and placement are independent from one item to another.

title: VR Children EMT test Reports
section: VR test results in different ages
text:
VR test results in different ages





Overall there seems to be a trend of older children to make more mistakes and have lower accuracy, especially in the 4 items difficutly. But the effect seems to be limited to men.











Note



There are a few possible explanations of the effect of age being reversed.

The data are missing the time component, so we do not kno how long it actually took the children to answer or how much they moved in the environemnt
It is possible, that the researcher might have been more supportive with the younger children
Finally, it is possible that the researcher might have removed the cognitive load for the task for the young children (as is suggested in the thesis, that the reearcher kept helping children unable to control the environment on their own), but information about whom has been helped is missing.




Total error
We then looked at the mean relative accuracy in all trials as the effect of age.


# A tibble: 141 × 17
# Groups:   name, age_months, error_type [141]
   name   age_month all_trials_error all_trials_avg_relative_error
   <chr>      <dbl>            <dbl>                         <dbl>
 1 Adélka        72                5                        0.333 
 2 Adélka        72                6                        0.478 
 3 Adélka        72                0                        0     
 4 Alenka        71                6                        0.467 
 5 Alenka        71                1                        0.0833
 6 Alenka        71                0                        0     
 7 Alfonz        74                9                        0.756 
 8 Alfonz        74                1                        0.0667
 9 Alfonz        74                0                        0     
10 Alia          69                6                        0.533 
# ℹ 131 more rows
# ℹ 13 more variables: all_trials_avg_relative_correct <dbl>, school <chr>,
#   gender <chr>, age_year <dbl>, birthday <dttm>, testing_date <chr>,
#   age_months <dbl>, difficulty <dbl>, error_value <dbl>,
#   relative_error_value <dbl>, made_error <lgl>, relative_correct <dbl>,
#   error_type <chr>


We fitted a linear model (estimated using ML) to predict all_trials_avg_relative_correct with age_months, gender, difficulty and error_type (formula: all_trials_avg_relative_correct ~ age_months * gender + difficulty + error_type). The model’s explanatory power is substantial (R2 = 0.47). The model’s intercept, corresponding to age_months = 0, gender = female, difficulty = 0 and error_type = incorrect_object_order, is at 0.57 (95% CI [-0.03, 1.17], t(135) = 1.86, p = 0.063). Within this model:

The effect of age months is statistically non-significant and positive (beta = 3.74e-04, 95% CI [-8.32e-03, 9.07e-03], t(135) = 0.08, p = 0.933; Std. beta = 9.09e-03, 95% CI [-0.20, 0.22])
The effect of gender [male] is statistically non-significant and positive (beta = 0.61, 95% CI [-0.15, 1.37], t(135) = 1.58, p = 0.115; Std. beta = 0.16, 95% CI [-0.09, 0.41])
The effect of difficulty is statistically significant and positive (beta = 0.23, 95% CI [0.16, 0.30], t(135) = 6.84, p < .001; Std. beta = 1.04, 95% CI [0.74, 1.34])
The effect of error type [incorrect_placement] is statistically significant and positive (beta = 0.36, 95% CI [0.29, 0.42], t(135) = 10.59, p < .001; Std. beta = 1.61, 95% CI [1.31, 1.91])
The effect of error type [selection] is statistically non-significant and negative (beta = -8.21e-03, 95% CI [-0.02, 2.66e-03], t(135) = -1.48, p = 0.139; Std. beta = -0.20, 95% CI [-0.46, 0.06])

Standardized parameters were obtained by fitting the model on a standardized version of the dataset. 95% Confidence Intervals (CIs) and p-values were computed using a Wald t-distribution approximation.

title: EMT manuscript
text:
Error description
Participant can make one of four distinct errors:

Item selection error: the participant selected the wrong item when given the option at the beginning of the recollection trial
Incorrect placement: the participant placed the item in a wrong location
Object order error: the participant placed the item in a wrong order (different from the order in the instruction)
Location order error: the participant placed the item (correct or incorrect) in a possible location, but different from the order in the instruction






The object order error and location order errors are in our implementation identical, as it is generally true that when participants places the object in a wrong location, they will also place the object in a wrong order. There are other implementations where the object order error is calculated differently, so the two can be exclusive, but in our case the correlation between object order error and location error is 1 (tau = 1.00, z = 12.55, p < .001), so we left only object order error in the analyses

Relative accuracy
As there is a difference in the potential number of errors possible at different difficulties (for example, you cannot make four selection mistakes out of three items), we also calculated the relative accuracy (1 - errors/maximum posibble errors). So the number 1 in relative accuracy means the best possible performance. This should allow us to consider the performance across different difficulties.

title: EMT manuscript
text:
Effect of age on performance
We fitted a linear mixed model (estimated using REML and nloptwrap optimizer) to predict relative_correct with age_months and gender (formula: relative_correct ~ age_months * gender). The model included name as random effect (formula: ~1 | name). The model’s total explanatory power is very weak (conditional R2 = 0.02) and the part related to the fixed effects alone (marginal R2) is of 0.01. The model’s intercept, corresponding to age_months = 0 and gender = female, is at 0.76 (95% CI [0.10, 1.43], t(417) = 2.27, p = 0.024). Within this model:

The effect of age months is statistically non-significant and positive (beta = 3.74e-04, 95% CI [-9.26e-03, 0.01], t(417) = 0.08, p = 0.939; Std. beta = 6.54e-03, 95% CI [-0.16, 0.17])
The effect of gender [male] is statistically non-significant and positive (beta = 0.61, 95% CI [-0.23, 1.45], t(417) = 1.43, p = 0.155; Std. beta = 0.12, 95% CI [-0.09, 0.32])
The effect of age months × gender [male] is statistically non-significant and negative (beta = -8.20e-03, 95% CI [-0.02, 3.84e-03], t(417) = -1.34, p = 0.181; Std. beta = -0.14, 95% CI [-0.35, 0.07])

Standardized parameters were obtained by fitting the model on a standardized version of the dataset. 95% Confidence Intervals (CIs) and p-values were computed using a Wald t-distribution approximation.
There is no significant effect of age on the performance in the VR task. No effect of gender or the interaction between the two either.
ale lze dokladovat srovnáním děti vs. dospělí u 5 objektů - různé typy chyb připravit i graf a skupinovou statistiku srovnávající Relative accuracy ukázat i všechny náročnosti? děti 3,4,5, dospělí -5,7,9?
